results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 27]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film is the second of two that capture a family holiday to far north Queensland and the Great Barrier Reef in May, 1975.

The Gadsden family travel by yacht to visit a tropical shore, enjoy an evening barbeque, go scuba diving and bask in the sun. They then travel to the town of Kuranda by train going through some spectacular rainforest scenery on their way.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:22:00 passenger yacht ‘Tiki’ anchors off an island and lets down a rowboat.
00:00:40:00 wallabies and kangaroos join the travellers for lunch
00:00:59:00 a kangaroo eating bread from its paws
00:01:31:00 old coral and shells on a beach
00:02:00:00 various efforts to break open a coconut
00:03:07:00 eating the coconut
00:03:20:00 tropical flowers, banana trees, palms and views around the landscape
00:04:12:00 lunch being set up on the beach – cutting vegetables and a makeshift barbeque plate on the sand
00:04:23:00 entering the water for snorkelling
00:04:49:00 sausages and onion rings on the barbeque plate with flames underneath
00:05:34:00 serving food from the barbeque to the travellers
00:05:57:00 the travellers picnic on the beach
00:06:18:00 sunbathing on the beach
00:07:00:00 speeding across the water
00:07:05:00 pamphlet for ‘Cairns-Kuranda’ rail trip showing the route the travellers will follow.
00:07:25:00 lovely old train
00:07:45:00 passengers boarding a train at a rail station
00:07:54:00 views from the moving train - the track below, sugar cultivation and lush hills
00:08:23:00 ‘Redlynch’ rail station with glimpses of pot plants and ferns typical of Queensland
00:09:05:00 scenic views and waving children
00:09:25:00 view of the train snaking ahead
00:10:00:00 views of the lush landscape from a higher vantage point
00:10:25:00 the train travels through tunnels and close vegetation and local onlookers standing by the tracks
00:10:36:00 train travels over a lovely old wooden bridge as it rises higher into the forest covered hills
00:10:58:00 a waterfall
00:11:30:00 looking out over fields to the sea as the train keeps moving along
00:11:44:00 train travels past labourers – probably from sugar cane fields
00:12:00:00 a sign for ‘Barron Falls’
00:12:29:00 the camera inadvertently captures a fashion moment from the 1970s – long hair in low ‘pigtails’ tied with equally long green narrow ribbons
00:12:44:00 the Gadsden travellers looking out the train window
00:12:54:00 Jess Gadsden among other sightseers hopping back onto the train from a lookout point
00:13:20:00 coming into the picturesque Kuranda rail station filled with pot plants and foliage and views around the station
00:14:16:00 sign for ‘Kuranda’
00:14:33:00 the Gadsden travellers enjoy a beer whilst at Kuranda Station

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 26]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film is part one of two films that capture a family holiday to the far north region of Queensland and the Great Barrier Reef in May, 1975.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:14:00 Jess Gadsden and her son approach a Douglas DC9 Ansett airplane on the tarmac
00:00:18:00 Ansett staff boarding the airplane wearing uniforms in a popular 1970s burnt orange fashion colour
00:00:31:00 the Gadsden’s are filmed disembarking from the plane
00:00:46:00 members of the family pack a Holden station wagon car
00:00:50:00 a map of the holiday route where we can see Palm Cove in Queensland
00:01:24:00 scenic views looking toward the hills in the hinterland and of the beach
00:02:34:00 Jess Gadsden in a pink headscarf headed for the beach and then turns to wave at the camera
00:02:55:00 scenes of the mountains and rivers in the Daintree Forest
00:03:12:00 Daintree Ferry crossing a river and approaching the bank
00:05:45:00 filmmaker Ron Gadsden being filmed whilst harness fishing from their deep sea fishing charter boat
00:08:16:00 seabirds gathering on a sandbar
00:08:48:00 snorkelling in the waters around the boat
00:09:42:00 Jess Gadsden prepares lunch in very small quarters on the boat
00:09:54:00 three members of the family are rowed ashore
00:10:19:00 a huge gathering of Sooty Tern (Sterna Fuscata) seabirds on the shore
00:11:45:00 speeding through the water
00:12:29:00 passenger boats at a pier
00:12:55:00 seabirds diving for fish
00:13:47:00 an old long pier
00:14:05:00 showing off ‘who has caught which fish?’
00:14:34:00 sailing away from piers, boats and a hilly coastline and passing by an old rusting, older ship – possibly a tanker
00:15:05:00 fishing off the back of the boat as it speeds through the water
00:16:15:00 passengers in their ‘Guilder III Cairns’ t-shirts
00:16:55:00 baiting the hook

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 22]
results.brief_description:

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel contains yacht racing at Davies Bay Yacht Club in Melbourne and at Lake Eppalock in Victoria. Footage shows the club members preparing yachts and sailing as well as the family and friends who are watching.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:02:50:00 children gathered at a berthed yacht
00:03:08:00 “Cheeky Chic” berthed yacht
00:03:32:00 competition rescue boat speeding away from a line up of competing yachts in preparation for the race
00:07:23:00 expansive view of yachts on the water
00:09:12:00 family members watching from the bank

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 19]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film is in two parts. Part one is of the Gadsden family farm ‘Mooltunya’ in country Victoria. The filmmaker’s wife Jess Gadsden attends her horses, dressed for the farm in gumboots and one of her many headscarfs (seen throughout the films).

The second part contains a family holiday to Alice Springs and surrounding areas which Ronald introduces by filming from a light plane on the approach to the Outback. Their first stop is to Flynn’s Grave memorial for John Flynn who among other achievements for the Outback, lobbied for what would become the Flying Doctor Service. Ronald’s camera shows an appreciation for the landscape they travel through – eucalypts, wildflowers and bees, bushland, rocks formations, dusty roads and the rock wallabies at the MacDonnell Ranges and Uluru. The reel shows a snapshot of Alice Springs in 1978, cars – kombi vans, utes and sedans, seventies fashion including clogs, denim skirts, flares and sunglasses. There are sequences of horseback riding through the bush where Mrs Gadsden shows her prowess among less confident riders and climbing Uluru.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:03:22:00 huge boulders sitting either side of a shed
00:07:17:00 goanna on rocks
00:8:16:00 to 00:09:00:00 wing span and over Uluru (Ayre’s Rock at that time)
00:10:07:00 ancient Aboringinal rock paintings
00:11:40:00 walking up Uluru (Ayre’s Rock at that time)
00:12:30:00 Ronald and family climb Uluru and find the descent difficult – reinforced by sign warning of the dangers of the climb.

Their first stop is to Flynn’s Grave memorial for John Flynn who among other achievements for the Outback, lobbied for what would become the Flying Doctor Service. Ronald’s camera shows an appreciation for the landscape they travel through – eucalypts, wildflowers and bees, bushland, rocks formations, dusty roads and the rock wallabies at the MacDonnell Ranges and Uluru. The reel shows a snapshot of Alice Springs in 1978, cars – kombi vans, utes and sedans, seventies fashion including clogs, denim skirts, flares and sunglasses. There are sequences of horseback riding through the bush where Mrs Gadsden shows her prowess among less confident riders and climbing Uluru.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:03:22:00 huge boulders sitting either side of a shed
00:07:17:00 goanna on rocks
00:8:16:00 to 00:09:00:00 wing span and over Uluru (Ayre’s Rock at that time)
00:10:07:00 ancient Aboringinal rock paintings
00:11:40:00 walking up Uluru (Ayre’s Rock at that time)
00:12:30:00 Ronald and family climb Uluru and find the descent difficult – reinforced by sign warning of the dangers of the climb.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 25]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is a series of scenarios based on a question which is also the title of the reel: ‘Where is it?’ and features Kenneth’s son-in-law Bob Wootton as the person looking for the answer and responding to each segment. Kenneth has Bob look in a book from a bookshelf which contains the hand written sequence titles. Kenneth also uses both black and white and colour sequences to add to the more dramatic feel of the reel. Kenneth has Bob pondering the title questions through the sequences as well as laughing at the end of some. the reel ends with Bob laughing uproariously.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:57:00 first colour scenario begins with title ‘Mr McCraw’s Orchids’ showing us Mr McCraw among his orchid plants in a hothouse as well as Kenneth’s favoured individual shots of individual blooms.

00:02:29:00 we see the next sub title, ‘Eastern Beach Geelong’ followed by colour footage of children playing in the water, foreshore recreational equipment such as diving boards and waterwheels, piers and crowds on the boardwalks and swimmers in and out of the water.

00:05:18:00 several yachts appear in the sea in what could be a race.

00:05:44:00 Bob opens the book again to the sub title ‘Skating at St Moritz’ followed by a colour sequence of a large scale ice skating show involving multiple performers and skotches at St Moritz, (presumably) in Melbourne’s St Kilda.

00:07:45:00 starts with the sub titles, ‘Hobbies - What is yours? Is it Model Boats?’ with Bob gazing toward footage of some intricate model boats and ships sailing and steaming around a shallow (and what appears to be purpose built) pool. The pool is surrounded by older children who appear to be operating the models.

00:14:52:00 Bob reveals the next question ‘or is it Model Trains?’. Here Kenneth shows us a group of men who operate model trains on a track raised high enough from the ground that they are able to ride the trains which seem to operate by steam.

00:18:21:00 ‘Or is it like mine - The Camera?’. Here we see a man in a park with what looks like a ‘box brownie’ camera taking pictures of seemingly random women (though we have seen one of them in other reels).

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 14]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

In this film titled ‘By Road to Adelaide’, the Rankine family travel to Adelaide. The footage that Kenneth takes along the way is a wonderful insight into holiday life on the road in the forties. Mrs Rankine and Bettye Rankine actively take part in the film by posing with the car along the road, in the gardens, at an Adelaide cafe and at flooded roads on the return trip. This reel uses the credit ‘An A.C. Rankine Film’ (rather than KenRa presents) and sequence title cards.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:19:00 ‘By Road to Adelaide’ and “Between Heywood and Mr Gambier”.

00:00:40:00 Mrs Rankine and Bettye Rankine pose for Kenneth’s camera in and around the family car, on a wide country road and at a milestone marked 241 (miles) and M (Melbourne).

00:01:42:00 Bettye is sitting on the running board of their car; luggage trunk strapped to the rear of the vehicle (rather than a carboot).

00:02:16:00 sign for the ‘South Australia Border’.

00:02:25:00 ‘Mt Gambier and The Lakes’, gardens, Blue Lake, flowers, treetops, a quick shot of a town.

00:05:12:00 ‘Kingston to Meningie’ shows us another lake which could be the ‘Pink Salt Lake’ at Meningie because footage shows reeds and grasses and a view of Mrs Rankine and Bettye standing on what seems like a salt plain before looking cold and seeking refuge in the car.

00:06:43:00 ‘Tailem Bend and nearing Adelaide’ where we see more salty landscape and lake and the travellers taking off from a tiny township.

00:07:28:00 ‘Adelaide the City and Gardens’ after which we look along North Terrace, and at busy city street. Mrs Rankine and Bettye are dressed more formally whilst meeting with a companion whose hair is a great example of a popular forties hairstyle inspired by Hollywood - the ‘Betty Grable updo’. This woman holds a tray of what appears to be ceramic craft work for the camera.

00:08:42:00 Bettye and her mother in a cafe, being served by a waitress in a uniform.

00:09:14:00 river views followed by the Adelaide City Bridge and the River Torrens Foobridge; these scenes are filmed from a boat on the river.

00:13:54:00 Bettye Rankine holding a koala in front of a garden water fountain.

00:14:28:00 ‘Port Elliot and Victor Harbour’ appears followed by great examples of 1940’s canvas holiday tents pitched directly on a beach.

00:15:45:00 ‘Homeward Bound Through the Floods’ introduces the last scenes which is footage of flooded roads. These scenes show the difficulty of travelling distances on country roads in this era.

This film, ‘The Sequel’, shows various snapshots of his travels almost as if these scenes are the offcuts of other reels. It is more difficult to locate his footage as Kenneth has not included his usual signs and location titles.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:06:00 title ‘The Sequel’ followed by scenes of waterways, a building with razorwire brick fence, houses, sloping green landscapes and various sea vessels back on the water - ferries, larger and smaller boats and sailing boats all in quick succession.

00:02:08:00 a train carrying coal, then more waterways including a road causeway across the water, a large church and a large hill and more water scenes.

00:02:38:00 prosperous looking farmland, market gardens and houses on a hillside, trees and hills and the sea.

00:03:20:00 old, crumbling buildings on a large scale; a newer house and a woman chopping wood followed by scenes of houses. a town street and farmland near a river and hills.

00:04:30:00 ‘Blue Horizon’ title begins a sequence of houses and a town along a river and the sea, Bettye Rankine and Bob Wootton walking on the sand.

00:05:35:00 the first of a few upside-down frames appear - a church and a town. These are followed by scenes of a large and possibly industrial country town near the sea.

00:07:17:00 shot of a steam train and an engine reversing into a crowded station.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 11]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is a scenic tour of mostly seaside places, from Sydney Harbour and Port Phillip Bay to a brief look at Phillip Island. The Rankine family members feature and are joined by Bob Wootton late in the reel who contributes to their roadside picnic by cooking meat on a barbecue over a fire in a tin. Kenneth uses individual title cards to clearly point out the locations he is filming and fnishes sunset scenes. Kenneth also uses title cards to introduce each sequence.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:12:00 ‘Sydney and the Harbour’, views across the Harbour to residential areas; Kenneth appears to be filming from a vantage point on the water.

00:01:07:00 Harbour Bridge followed by shots of ferries and dockside buildings; a larger ship comes into view as well as Fort Denison Island and a longer shot of the Harbour Bridge.

00:03:20:00 ‘Manly’, the pier and some buildings.

00:03:40:00 shops and shoppers with the camera taking in the view down to the Harbour; beach scenes and a large ship in the distance.

00:04:48:00 ‘Blue Mountains from Echo Point’ is followed by dramatic views over the mountain ranges and rock formations.

00:05::39:00 the Rankines meeting some other travellers along a walking track.

00:05:51:00 scenes of a sports club and members relaxing, the men are in blazers.

00:06:16:00 ‘The Cascades Leura’, waterfalls, a footbridge and Mrs and Miss Rankine splashing at the foot of a waterfall.

00:07:41:00 a band playing in a large rotunda Spanish exhibition dancing for onlookers; this sequence also shows good examples of vintage bathers.

00:08:32:00 ‘St Kilda’, the St Kilda Botanical Gardens.

00:09:17:00 scenes looking across Pier Rd to the St Kilda Pier, kiosk and a yacht followed by shots of swimmers.

00:10:07:00 ‘At Elwood’ shows more examples of vintage bathing costumes with a beach coat and caps and launching a sail boat straight from the sand.

00:11:14:00 ‘At Mid Brighton’ small craft bobbing in shallow waters followed by a yacht race and Kenneth’s daughter with binoculars looking on.

00:13:07:00 ‘At Sandringham’ shows another sequence of swimmers, people sunbathing, sailboats and diving from what might be an old piece of a jetty, sitting on rocks on the shoreline; there are bathing boxes in the background on the beach.

00:16:50:00 a small boat being hoisted down from a shed and rolled on tracks into the water.

00:18:00:00 onwards we see the Rankines joined by Bob Wootton who contributes to their roadside picnic with his meat patties/ burgers, barbecued over a fire in a tin.

00:18:32:00 ‘Phillip Island’ is introduced with a postcard before coastal views and several shots of koalas in trees, the family wandering along a road.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film shows tugboats assisting ships into the piers at the Port of Melbourne and stars the “James Paterson” boat on which Kenneth is filming. The scenes in the reel show a lost world of shipping and the manual labour of port operations. The reel ends with the ‘James Paterson’ tugboat at the dock.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:30:00 title card ‘Pushing and Pulling’ and “starring James Paterson and Norman C. McBain”. Shortly after, we see a tugboat named ‘James Paterson’.

00:03:31:00 scenes of the workings of the tugboats in assisting ships in and out of port, stoking the engine fires, ships crews looking down from the great height of their vessels whilst the tugboats manoeuvre around them.

00:03:45:00 shots of boats and water and a large ship ‘Pipiriki’ leaving a pier and being towed by a tugboat from where Kenneth is filming, presumably on the ‘James Paterson’; we see shots of a harbour and ships and boats passing by as well as one the tugboat operator at the wheel.

00:04:07:00 we see the ship ‘Sanoma’ followed by men working lines on the tugboat alongside the ship.

00:07:55:00 ‘Melbourne Star’ ship, the ‘Wombat’ tugboat and ‘River Murumbidgee’.

00:09:15:00 we see a close up of rope work by the crew of the ‘Clan Macaulay’.

00:10:05:00 shows a great closeup shot of workers chatting on the tugboat.

00:11:50:00 a good shot of one of the dockside piers.

00:12:13:00 sequence from this point shows a ship hoisted into dry dock - Kenneth uses shots of the boat stop signal, a dry dock supply shop and the pier to emphasise the dry dock surrounds.

00:13:00:00 the scene changes to night time on the water followed by some passenger ships.
